Award.AwardTitle: Systematics of fungi associated to wild rubber (Hevea spp.) trees in the Amazon basin: Searching for specialized biocontrol agents against economically important plant pathogens
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project utilizes the power of phylogenetic systematics to identify and classify specialized species of fungi associated with wild rubber trees (Hevea). A goal of the project is to document fungal species that can be used in biological control of devastating Hevea diseases, including the South American Leaf Blight (SALB). The project will: characterize fungal species associated with wild Hevea species by collecting and identifying the fungi using modern phylogenetic tools; elucidate coevolutionary patterns between fungi and their hosts, and host preferences, by analyzing and comparing phylogenies of selected fungi and their corresponding plant hosts; and identify biocontrol agents against Hevea diseases by evaluating selected fungi in biocontrol assays.

The largest and most productive commercial rubber plantations are in Asia and Africa. This is due to the difficulty of establishing plantations in regions where SALB exists. SALB is not yet present in Africa or Asia, and its potential spread to these continents represents significant biological and economic concerns. Even though potential impacts of SALB are large, few control methods have been published. Fungal biocontrol against Hevea diseases could be part of this solution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

This project characterized the fungal endosymbionts associated to wild rubber (Hevea spp.) trees. A goal of the project was to discover and document fungal species that can be used in biological control of devastating Hevea diseases, including the South American Leaf Blight (SALB) and Corynespora leaf blight. The premise of this goal was to find beneficial fungi in the area of origin of the rubber trees, which is the Amazon basin. These beneficial fungi have been associated with the trees for millions of years and have been protecting the trees from pests and diseases. Our project found that wild rubber trees have about 4000 species of endosymbiotic fungi and that the most abundant species in adult trees have beneficial properties. We also found that the fungal species in adult trees are very different from those in seedlings. The most abundant species in seedlings have disease potential and may add to ecological hypotheses on the reasons behind plant species distribution in tropical forests (e.g. Janzen-Connell hypothesis).

We then selected the beneficial fungi from adult trees and tested them in biocontrol experiments against important diseases. We found that these fungi have a strong effect against the diseases, more than other known biocontrol agents. 

Broader impacts:

The largest and most productive commercial rubber plantations are in Asia and Africa. This is due to the difficulty of establishing plantations in regions where SALB exists. SALB is not yet present in Africa or Asia, and its potential spread to these continents represents significant biological and economic concerns. Even though potential impacts of SALB are large, few control methods have been published. The fungi that we found could be part of this solution.

This project also trained many undergraduate and graduate students in the US. In addition, it built scientific capacity abroad (Peru and Brazil) by training several undergraduate and graduate students.
